sub_title: Assistant Professor in Computational Metabolomics at Bioinformatics Group at Wageningen University
summary:
Molecules are everywhere. The diverse structures and functions of small and specialized molecules have always fascinated me. Specialized molecules play key roles in nature as inter-species and even inter-kingdom messengers or as chemical weapons to deter or eliminate­ competing organisms nearby. Furthermore, these specialized molecules are also important components of food often determining crop growth and fitness and their nutritional value. I recognise three paths to better understand complex specialized metabolite mixtures: i) increased metabolite annotation power, ii) chemically-informed comparative metabolomics, and iii)  linked metabolomics profiles to function and genotype/genomic information.

My research vision is to close the gap between what we can see in metabolomics and what we can actually learn from it. This will enable biochemical interpretation of spectral data obtained from complex metabolite mixtures through structural and functional annotations. This will depend on finding out: i) which structural information is encoded in metabolomics data; ii) how novel chemistry can be recognised in spectral data, and iii) how to effectively identify relevant metabolite groups in metabolomics profiles of complex metabolite mixtures? 

My research agenda is to develop algorithms and models to improve structural annotation of metabolite features and to obtain direct biochemical knowledge from metabolomics profiles. In my group, I will develop computational metabolomics approaches inspired by two other fields - that of natural language processing (NLP) and genomics. For example, I have demonstrated the use of topic modeling NLP algorithms to discover substructures from metabolomics profiles, and I am currently pioneering the use of word embedding NLP approaches to aid in metabolomics analyses. For example, linking the outcome of genomics and metabolomics data mining tools will accelerate the natural products discovery field by making connections between biosynthetic gene clusters and spectra of the molecular structures they encode for. I will use the plant root microbiome and human food metabolome as prime applications since they represent complex metabolite mixtures full of yet unknown metabolic matter that once elucidated will boost our insights in molecular mechanisms underpinning the regulation of growth, development, and health.

publications.name: Systematic metabolite identification and annotation in complex biological extracts - combining robust mass spectrometry fragmentation and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy

authors.headline: Assistant Professor in Computational Metabolomics at Bioinformatics Group at Wageningen University

profile_positions.description: I will build a group that will work on improving the use of untargeted metabolomics data through developing, improving, and enhancing metabolomics data analysis tools. Metabolite annotation and identification based on spectral data of complex metabolite mixtures remains a key challenge for the field. The human (gut) and plant (root) microbiomes have been shown to play pivotal roles for growth and health of humans and plants, and the interaction of host, diet, and microbial molecules is likely to mediate inter kingdom communication. Thus, finding the origin of molecules in a complex mixture is critical, for example to recognise microbial, diet, and host-related metabolites in microbiome samples. In addition, the food metabolome that is studied by foodomics is another intriguing area that requests innovative approaches to unravel metabolites derived from various food resources and how they get processed outside and inside the human body. These are the challenges that my group will take on to accelerate natural products, foodomics, and microbiome research!
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor in computational metabolomics at Bioinformatics Group at Wageningen University

profile_positions.description: Being awarded with a 3-years grant from the Netherlands eScienceCenter and NWO, we will work to bring together genomics and metabolomics specialized metabolite data sets to enable mining for novel chemistries and enhanced metabolite annotation strategies.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher in genome and metabolome mining

profile_positions.description: Postdoctoral researcher exploring novel approaches to combine metabolome and genome mining strategies to discover specialized microbial molecules.
profile_positions.title: Postdoc

profile_positions.location: University of Glasgow, Glasgow, United Kingdom
profile_positions.description:
Feedback on Justin's work from Professor Mike Barrett:

Justin has proven himself to be leading authority in the highly skilled area of metabolite identification through fragmentation. He has been producing high quality work and publishing good papers. His work on drug identification is ground breaking. He also contributes positively to the metabolomics workflows and community in Polyomics and makes a key bridge to clinical scientists. Justin makes novel things happen and gets things done in a timely fashion.

Short description of project:
Analysis of mass spectral fragmentation data to get a comprehensive view on drug metabolites present in urine of patients having hypertension.
profile_positions.title: Research Associate in Mass Fragmental Analysis of Drug Metabolism

profile_positions.description:
During the fellowship, I will work on exploring the mass spectrometer fragmentation methods as aid in metabolite annotation and identification in biomarker discovery studies. Also, I will assist in implementation of mass fragmentation methodology in the current metabolomics workflow used within Glasgow Polyomics.

http://www.polyomics.gla.ac.uk/
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow

profile_positions.description:
Supporting projects in metabolite annotation and identification by developing protocols for using NMR and mass spectrometry as complementary platforms for metabolite identification.
http://www.polyomics.gla.ac.uk/
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant in Metabolomics at Glasgow Polyomics

profile_positions.description: During this postdoc I fully identified several valerolactone conjugates and quantified the isolated amounts using NMR. Additionally, epicatechin breakdown products present in rat urine and tissues were studied using LC-MS profiles in combination with radioactive monitoring.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistent at Plant Products and Human Nutrition Group

profile_positions.description: Will work on different projects involved in metabolite identification and annotation.
profile_positions.title: Junior Researcher

profile_positions.description:
During my research I am developing methodologies for faster identification of metabolites present in complex extracts derived from plants like tomato and Arabidopsis as well as human biofluids. Therefore, I set up two analytical platforms. At Plant Research International, the set up fragments metabolites in a robust way and measures the masses of the metabolites very accurate. The other platform at the Laboratory of Biochemistry can trap compounds based on their mass peaks in a chromatogram, and then the compounds can be transferred to the NMR for subsequent NMR analysis. 
My PhD project is embedded within the Metabolite Identification cluster of the Netherlands Metabolomics Centre.
Keywords: mass spectrometry (MS), nuclear magentic resonance (NMR), analytical chemistry, plant extracts, human bodyfluids
